conclusion: Need to use the ideal gas law to relate pressure, volume, temperature, and amount of gas.
Diagram shows the relationship between pressure and volume for different states of the gas.
State A corresponds to a pressure of 3 × 10⁵ Pa and a volume of 1 × 10⁻³ m³. State C corresponds to a pressure of 1 × 10⁵ Pa and a volume of 3 × 10⁻³ m³.
Use the ideal gas law, PV = nRT, where P is pressure, V is volume, n is the number of moles, R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.
Since the temperature T is constant, use the relationship PV = nRT.
Calculate the number of moles n using the initial and final states.
Substitute the known values into the ideal gas law: 3 × 10⁵ × 1 × 10⁻³ = n × 1 × 10⁵ × 3 × 10⁻³.
Calculate the temperature T at state C using the ideal gas law: T_C = 0.333 × 1 × 10⁵ / 1 × 10⁵ = 33.3 K.
Convert the temperature from Kelvin to Celsius: T_C = 33.3 K = 27 + 33.3 = 60.3 °C.
Since the temperature at state A is 27°C, the temperature at state C is also 27°C.
The final answer is the temperature at state C, which is 27°C.
